content.body: othermaciej: for some reason, on my system, no progress messages seem to get written to the console during the process of updating to a new nightly build
or maybe I'm looking in the wrong place

but I just updated to the latest nightly and when I go to check All Message in Console.app, I see just one Safari/WebKit-related message there: 10/03/12 10:37:32 Safari[43511] WebKit r55834 initialized.
MikeSmith: I know nothing about the nightly update mechanism since I always just build my own
ah yeah

well, I just mentioned it because bdash suggested checking the console messages as a way of troubleshooting any install problems.. I guess I'll ping him on IRC when he's around again and ask him if I need to switch on verbosity somewhere or something
othermaciej: anyway, about doing the regular checks/reports on resolution status, etc., of HTML WG bugs, I definitely want to help out with that
and with anything else we can think of that would help with getting issues resolved, and help with getting us closer to being ready for LC
I'll start doing the 2nd thing you mentioned
http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/html-wg/20100311#l-88

"someone should be checking bugs in RESOLVED state to make sure they contain the required info (the Editor's Response, a link to the spec diff if there was actually a spec change, a rationale that is actually some sort of meaningful rationale"
MikeSmith: great - I'm going to mass-move the bugs that predate the policy info VERIFIED tomorrow, and the rest can be done at any time, no set schedule
OK
It will help in general if we had some direct SQL query access to the bugzilla DB
maybe I can get that
but rather than checking it manually, I'm hoping there is maybe a way that I can write a script to generate report" is something that of course needs to be checked by a human
but having the Editor's Decision comments in some kind of easy-to-scan report form would make that much easier
a script would be great
there's actually a couple of scripts we could use:
- Script to compile Editor's Resolution and spec diff link for bugs in RESOLVED (for verification)
(Hixie uses a consistent format so it shouldn't be too hard)
- Script to count bugs that are still not in a terminal state (anything but CLOSED or VERIFIED+NoReply)
- Script to generate a Disposition of Comments based on bugs that *are* in a terminal state (we'll need this for getting out of Last Call)
the last one we are absolutely going to need eventually, one way or the other
the other two I can definitely work on trying to get set up
I vaguely remember asking the systems team some time ago about if there were a way I could get SQL access to the bugzilla DB
but I can remember if the answer was a definition No, or just a "No, we'd rather you didn't do that, so we're not going to let you" No
.me notices new Audits tab in WebKit
including "Remove unused CSS rules"
this is nice
it would also be nice to have as an online checker somewhere
or maybe it already is
wow, I guess the Audits tab has been in there for a while.. Not sure how I missed it
I think the name "Audits" scared me off
if is said something more like "Optimize" that would be a lot more attractive
that's a good idea
"Audits" sounds like it will poke in your financial records
yeah
http://googlewebmastercentral.blogspot.com/2010/03/microdata-support-for-rich-snippets.html
wow, the news was posted on March 9?
anyway, so much for the argument about Microdata not having any implementation support
hey neat
anyone know if the changes discussed for the File API are going to make it?
in particular, moving .type to Blob and renaming .urn to .URL?
othermaciej: how do you think i should address the use case of allowing a canvas to be uploaded to a server?
Hixie: you mean other than the possibilities of uploading a data: URL or uploading the ImageData in a way you serialize yourself?
Hixie: I am going to try to get binary data on the agenda for the TC-39 meeting at Apple later this month, if they can be brought to actually care about the issue, then I'd recommend that
k, i'll delay a bit longer then
failing that i'll just provide a toBlob() to match toDataURL()

Hixie: I'm not super enthusiastic about the idea of using a File or Blob because it seems broken to me to use an interface that's intended for async-only access to persistently stored data for this use case
Hixie: but it may be better than nothing
yeah that's more or less my position
I am attempting to factor in a number of html5 elements to a page. When I have a number of javascripts, gifs, svg and xhtml:body sections, then a page can reach 500k.
This is the sort of size similar functionality is delivered by flash.
Though there is a presentation hint possible with flash.
The '...loading...' message.
Is there a function in html5 spec which does anything similar?
Google supports Microdata per @diveintomark
http://googlewebmastercentral.blogspot.com/2010/03/microdata-support-for-rich-snippets.html
oh hey, the IETF is having discussion on whether text/plain is still a suitable format on http://www.ietf.org/mail-archive/web/ietf/current/maillist.html
funny
hah. framing the discussion as PS/PDF vs. plain text as opposed to HTML vs plain text
yeah, I've no idea how you can even start with suggesting PDF
something must be seriously wrong in the workflow of that guy
and then the thread turn to .epub
wow
oh, I didn't get that far
goes back reading
oh, that's actually early on, I skipped a few fun emails it seems
wonders ow many messages it takes for someone to remind the others that this Web thing happened while they weren't paying attention
the credit goes to Julian: http://www.ietf.org/mail-archive/web/ietf/current/msg60576.html
i wonder why people refer to plain text as "ASCII"
RFC plain text is ASCII, but yeah, it's interesting that moving to UTF-8 plain text wasn't proposed
Japanese guy freaked out over moving away from ASCII: http://www.ietf.org/mail-archive/web/ietf/current/msg60589.html
the interwebs is full of fascinating plot twists
oh, it's mentioned later in the thread
as far as I can tell Julian and Tim are the only sane voices in that discussion
way to go IETF...
they are right that all the fancy graphics just detract from the essentials of the gaming experience
the best games are just plain text, like the original Star Trek
yeah
http://xkcd.com/91/
heh
"you don't need any extra junkware to be able to read the RFCs"
they should put that the RFC boilerplate
in bold type
and/or italiced
and in red
but they can't
that's not ASCII o_O
oh damn
I was going to say that they could make it hyperlink to a detailed explanation
You can read PDFs using less if you are cool enough. I have.
(be sure not the have flate streams in there, though, unless you can run deflate mentally)
hsivonen is cool
you can read a lot of stuff using strings(1)
with implied quotes in there somewhere
maybe around the word read
i read PNGs by reading the PNG spec and then opening in a hex editor
zcorpan: I think they like the word ASCII because is more l33t
welcome to our hackers club. we do everything in ASCII. if you dont like it, get out of the computer room and go eat lunch in the cafeteria or somewhere instead
that hackers club must have some kind of millennium bug...
they accidentally creating a worm hole with their mad hacking skillz and they are stuck in it
and happy to be stuck in it
is google's impl of microdata conforming?
zcorpan: dunno, but anyone wnting to use Google's impl for Microdata advocacy should find out.
where is Google's implementation of Microdata? Have they released the source, or just incorported it into their search engine somehow?
hsivonen, that's not how advocacy for RDFa worked...
or works, haven't followed it recently
wonders how long we'll have to wait before the lawyers at Google have sorted out VP8
annevk: This is Microdata advocacy's chance to hold the moral high ground compared to RDFa advocacy.
so I just noticed that it's effectively impossible to google for the phrase, "5 > 2"
that's kinda sad
hopefully it's a high priority bug
it should be!
(it's unbingable as well)
the other day I saw some people theorizing over what it might mean
apparently it was in a Google I/O presentation but not clarified; they thought it had something to do with Web 2.0
heh
was it in there as an inside joke or did they expect people to get the reference?
http://www.google.com/codesearch?hl=en&lr=&q=%5Cb5%5C+%3E%5C+2%5Cb&sbtn=Search
probably an inside joke; it has been an inside joke from the moment you made that t-shirt I think
http://www.w3.org/2010/02/rdfa/wiki/RDFa-DOM-API
we should make some new t-shirts
it's been an inside joke since before I made the t-shirt
5 > 2 is no longer an interesting statement
sadly 5 > f is not true (at least in hexadecimal)
<i> ♥ <html> is one I suggested for #fronteers once

would hypothesise that Google uses the same 'HTML' parser for Microdata as for RDFa, i.e. one that's more like an error-correcting XML parser, so it'll handle things like "

...

" as if they were nested
or s/<html>/HTML5/
so here's one thing I don't get about people making RDF APIs
why is the interface always a flat list of triples?
I thought the whole point of RDF was that it has a graph structure, and the interesting thing to do is to traverse or make queries against the graph
if you completely drop the graph structure, what's the point?
it would be like having a DOM API where the only way to traverse nodes was as a flat list of all the nodes in the document
that's cute
too bad HTML5 has no version indicator so you can't do it in the syntax
finally, a critical use case for a version indicator!
<i> ♥ <!doctype html> says enough
now we need some designer to make it look pretty :)
tragically monospace fonts don't seem to have a decent-looking solid heart glyph (at least not the ones on my machine)
I am amused that Mark Pilgrim still uses 5>2 as his twitter icon
I wonder how many of his followers get the reference
http://creatr.cc/creatr/logo/i%20hearts%20doctype%20html.png?1268387003
Is http://www.amazon.com/HTML5-Up-Running-Mark-Pilgrim/dp/0596806027/ref=pd_sim_b_1 the same content as Dive into HTML5?
hsivonen: yes
whoah there's a surprising number of HTML5 books now
othermaciej: really?
well, maybe I am naiive to be surprised
I didn't know any printed HTML5 books had been published yet other than the ones that got published here in Japan
if you search on Amazon you can see there's quite a few coming up
I see now
most by people I don't know, which is encouraging
http://www.amazon.com/dp/0321719913 by tantek
the book equivalent of vaporware, except I guess for Mark's, which is online already
*content of which is already online
notes that his video article is under BSD so someone could rip it off and use it in a book (assuming i understand the license correctly)
http://www.amazon.com/Introducing-HTML5-Voices-That-Matter/dp/0321687299/ref=pd_sim_sbs_b_2 brucel&remysharp
also notes that he is happy to review books on html5, for anyone writing such books
me sees franksalim as co-author on another of those books

I've volunteered to make some simple cross-browser <video> boilerplate and I can't decide if I should have unscripted Cortado fallback with the user of the cookbook having to put the video size and URL in multiple places or if I should have scripted fallback that copies the URL and size from the video element

not sure if it can be expressed as a t-shirt slogan

<[a-zA-Z][^>]*=\s*(("[^"]*)|('[^']*)|([^"']*))&(AElig|AMP|Aacute|Acirc|Agrave|Aring|Atilde|Auml|COPY|Ccedil|ETH|Eacute|Ecirc|Egrave|Euml|GT|Iacute|Icirc|Igrave|Iuml|LT|Ntilde|Oacute|Ocirc|Ograve|Oslash|Otilde|Ouml|QUOT|REG|THORN|Uacute|Ucirc|Ugrave|Uuml|Yacute|aacute|acirc|acute|aelig|agrave|amp|aring|atilde|auml|brvbar|ccedil|cedil|cent|copy|curren|deg|divide|eacute|ecirc|egrave|eth|euml|frac12|frac14|frac34|gt|iacute|i

uml|laquo|lt|macr|micro|middot|nbsp|not|ntilde|oacute|ocirc|ograve|ordf|ordm|oslash|otilde|ouml|para|plusmn|pound|quot|raquo|reg|sect|shy|sup1|sup2|sup3|szlig|thorn|times|uacute|ucirc|ugrave|uml|uuml|yacute|yen|yuml)[^;a-zA-Z0-9]
Philip`: the above should find no-semicolon entities in attribute value that's not followed by a-zA-Z0-9
Philip`: could you run a grep for that? :)

will try to remember it himself

ASCII not what the spec can do for you, ask what you can do for the spec
the Live DOM Viewer is buggy in Chrome
especially the w() function does not seem to execute instantly like I expect and like it does in other browsers
Hixie, ^^
So the main arguments for the RFC format seems to be "works for my 30-year old printer" and "it's eco-friendly"
Surely this is the perfect organization to lead us into the future
Dashiva: You seem to be concentrating on the logical arguments. The _main_ argument seems to be "get off my lawn"
Good thing there's nobody around to blow up the ascii for names thing as racism and western imperialism
I feel I should insert some sort of qualifier before "logical". Like "almost, but not"
from my programmer POV, ASCII manuals and references are much more convenient than PDFs
That's a false dilemma
(ASCII is a charset, not a file format)
erm, plain text
i thought you were arguing about format rather than charset
Both, really
well, with utf-8 i can get my cp437 box characters back
And with HTML I can have hyperlinks
Seriously I don't know why PDF is even being discussed
The question should be phrased as "why aren't RFCs being published as (utf-8) HTML"
Because that won't print on my 30-years old printer using tools made before HTML came into being
To which the correct response is "so?"
"Take your technical arguments elsewhere, whippersnapper"

Anyway plain text RFCs are inconvenient too transcribe by hand-of-monk with illuminated letters since the number of characters per line is highly variable in that case, and the hardcoded headers and page breaks confuse the monks no end
s/too/to/
hand-of-monk is obsolete since RFC 1217
(replaced by hand-of-monkey)
If you allow people to write specs in HTML, soon they'll be using SVG graphics and embedding JavaScript in every page
and there would be no end to the madness
Also, you can bet a lot of people would write their HTML-formatted specs in Microsoft Word
yeah, because that is exactly what happened at the W3C

Gosh, if only technology had advanced to the level where we could automatically check a file against a set of rules before publication. Then one could enforce whatever rules one pleased and avoid that whole issue
It's sad that no one has managed to develop such a system
governments would pay millions

(because it's not using anything like an HTML parser when parsing the HTML)
Interesting.
Well, that's equal opportunity at least
Hixie had sort of vaguely hinted at some point that Google might possibly be using an HTML5 parser for some things internally.
Clearly this isn't one of those things
This isn't a HTMLx parser for any value of x
It seemed kind of like XML5 minus the complex bits (doctypes etc) when I last looked
There's no such thing as an HTMLx parser for x < 5, at least if we're confining our discussion to real life.
Philip`: And minus the well-formedness?
I thought Ian once said they use some kind of graph representation

foo

bar correctly since that's a basic part of HTML syntax
Dashiva: I thought XML5 didn't do well-formedness
I thought it did, but with relaxed constraints

Google doesn't handle

foo

bar properly? o_O

I assume they use a different parser for serious things like search indexing
annevk: I vaguely remember him just saying they parse into some kind of internal representation that isn't RDF

Philip`, not this stuff
Philip`, because they want streaming and do not want to modify a tree
Philip`, but do want to recognize the effects of testtest
